item.title: The macro problem with microservices - Stack Overflow Blog
item.description: In just 20 years, software engineering has shifted from architecting monoliths with a single database and centralized state to microservices where everything is distributed across multiple containers, servers, data centers, and even continents. Distributing things solves scaling concerns, but introduces a whole new world of problems, many of which were previously solved by monoliths.
item.author: (Ryland Goldstein Head of Product at Temporal)

item.title: Learn C# with CSharpFritz - Ep10: SDK, Project Types, and Testing
item.description:
Let's start to write some real software and talk about the project system, the .NET SDK command-line tools, and write our first unit tests.
After the C# basics sessions are completed, which user interface framework do you want Fritz to walk through FIRST? Vote for your favorite with an emote at: https://github.com/csharpfritz/csharp_with_csharpfritz/issues/13
Questions: 00:31:15 - Will .NET Core eventually replace .NET Framework or .NET Standard? 00:35:1 - Do you feel like in a Linux platform when using command-line tools with .NET Core as a Microsoft Developer? 00:37:17 - Does .NET 5 have a x-platform GUI framework? 00:53:06 - What is the .NET command to only compile and not run the project? 01:02:20 - What's the story for sharing code to .NET Core 3.x projects?
Background Music is Harris Heller's Streambeats - Synthwave playlist, available royalty free at https://open.spotify.com/playlist/2gjWL0J5SQKceERGJ8Lb5e?si=hxqRoh0DSGei8eOu2vEsiA
Source code and interactive content from the stream are available at: https://github.com/csharpfritz/csharp_with_csharpfritz Watch live Mondays at 1300 UTC / 9a ET / 6a PT at: https://twitch.tv/visualstudio
item.author: (dotNET)

item.title: The Organic Web
item.description: If we lived close to nature in an agricultural society, the seasons as metaphor and fact would continually frame our lives. But the master metaphor for our era does not come from agriculture—it comes from manufacturing. We do not believe that we “grow” our lives—we believe that we “make” them. Just listen to how we use the word in everyday speech: we make time, make friends, make meaning, make money, make a living, make love. — Parker Palmer, “Let Your Life Speak” (97)

item.description: If the point of a startup is to create excess value then the startup needs an innovation that can be defended over time. This means the team must have a strategy to defend their position once they have mitigated uncertainty.

item.title: C# 9 records as strongly-typed ids - Part 2: ASP.NET Core route and query parameters
item.description: Last time, I explained how easy it is to use C# 9 record types as strongly-typed ids: public record ProductId(int Value); But unfortunately, we’re not quite done yet: there are a few issues to fix before our strongly-typed ids are really usable. For instance, ASP.NET Core doesn’t know how to handle them in route parameters or query string parameters. In this post, I’ll show how to address this issue. Model binding of route and query string parameters Let’s say we have an entity like this:
item.author:

Our course platform will help us to keep in touch.

item.title: Virtual desktops are an end-user window management feature, not a programmatic one | The Old New Thing
item.description: Virtual desktops are a window management feature, not a security feature or a performance feature. Furthermore, they are for end users to organize their windows, not for other programs to organize the windows. The purpose of the IVirtual­Desktop­Manager interface is to allow applications to take the virtual desktop state into account in a few application scenarios.
